This Company's system of submarine telegraph

communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

be marked Via Eastern.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria weekly as under for PIRAEUS (Athens), SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with the Orient Railways Express Service for VIENNA, BERLIN, PARIS & LONDON.
The S. S. Osmanieh will resume her express sailings on May 8.

PALESTINE - SYRIA MAIL SERVICE.–The fast steamers Prince Abbas and Assouan leave Alexandria alternately on Saturdays at 4 p.m. for Jaffa (for Jerusalem), Caiffa (for Nazareth), Beyrouth (for Damascus), Tripoli, Alexandretta, and Mersina, continuing in alternate weeks to Larnaca (Cyprus).

SUDAN DIRECT MAIL SERVICE.–The mail steamers Dakahlieh and Kosseir leave Suez alternately on Wednesdays at 5 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakim in connection with the Sudan Government Railways express serice to Khartoum.
RED SEA COASTING MAIL SERVICE.–Mail steamers leave Suez on Mondays at 5 p.m. for Tor (for Sinai), Yambo and Jeddah, continuing in alternate weeks to Port Sudan, Suakim, Massowah, Hodeidah and Aden
For further information refer to Co.'s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, Suez, or to THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd., HAMBURG-AMERIKA REISE-BUREAU or other Tourist Agencies.

div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. div.head: Mission to Sinai
div.p: It is announced that Naouin Bey Shoukair has been charged by the War Ministry with an important mission to the Sinai peninsula.

div.head: New Bourse Regulations.
div.p: The International Judiciary Commission will not meet before November to consider new regulations for the bourse and other questions.

div.head: Brindisi Mall.
div.p: The mail frojn Europe via Brindisi and Port Said will be distributed at the Alexandria Post Office at 4-30 this afternoon.

div.head: Government School Sports
div.p: The annual sports and gymnastic display of the Ras el Tin Government School will be held to-morrow afternoon, commencing at 3 p.m.

div.head: H H. 8. Aida.
div.p: H H.S Aida, of the Ports and Lighthouses Administration, left Alexandria yesterday afternoon for the Red Sea, Hanganab, and Port Sudan.

div.head: Postponed Concert.
div.p: The concert to be given at the New Khédivial Hotel, Alexandria, on Saturday by Mme. Meyer and hor pupils has been postponed -until Monday.

div.head: Exemption from Conscription.
div.p: The sums paid for exemption front conscription during January and February amounted to LE 50,900 as compared with L.E. 31,020 during thé samemonths of last year.

div.head: Creeks at Khartoum.
div.p: The Greeks Community in Khartoum have formed a rifle club. The inauguration ceremony* took place last week under the patinage of El-Lcwa Asser Pasha, Adjuntant General.

div.head: Malls by Motor
div.p: The Post Office Administration will receive up to and including t he 15th May tenders for the transport of mails by automobiles in Alexandria The terms of contract can be obtained at the secretary's office, G.P.O., Alexandria. Ait official notice with full details appears in our advertising columns.

div.head: A Dastardly Copt.
div.p: A brutal crime is reported from Slioubrn, Cairo. A Copt, persuaded of the infidelity of his wife, decided to put an end to hef life. With this object he first of all set fire to the bed on which the girl, who was only 16 years of age, was sleeping, hut, being wakened.by the heat of titer flames, she shouted for help, whereupon her husband seized a razor and cut her throat.

div.head: Well-Known Figure Disappears
div.p: The chief of the Montenegrin!! guardians of tho Anglo-Egyptian Bank, Nicolas Klopan, at Alexandria has died. He went on Sunday to Mex and was seized with on apoplectic stroke to which he succumbed. His family and his compatriots beg us to express their deep gratitude to Mr. H.P. Kinghnm, manager of the Anglo-Egyptian Bank, tho staff of the hank, and all those who were present at the funeral and wfho sent notes of sympathy.

div.head: Council of Discipline.
div.p: The mainour of Belbeis markaz, Mohamed Ali Effendi.was tried bv a Council of Discipline on the following charges :—that lie disobeyed orders in allowing an apprentice ghnffir clerk to receive public money, of which he emliezzel- ed a sum of L.E 34 ; that lie neglected to inspect the registers kept by the said clerk and did not enquire into the case of embezzlement ; and that lie failed to convene the Maglis Hnsbi for four months. He-' was found guilty of ull the charges, but on appeal, the higher court lessened his sentence of suspension from duty for two months with forfeiture of pay, to suspension of 15 (lays. The yourt of appeal found him guilty of the first and second charges only.

div.head: Creak Steamer Ashore.
div.p: The Greek S.S. Adelphotis, 1,700 tons laden with paving stones from Naples for Alexandria, ran aground at -I a.in. in hazy weather, about ten .miles West of Agami point. The Deputy Director General of Ports and Lighthouses went out to her in the forenoon in one of the port tugs and brought to Alexandria the Captain, 12 passengers and 1 I of the crew at 5 p.m with their luggage, reporting that the ship is on the inside of a small reef 1 1/2 miles from the shore at Kreah, which is 5 miles from Arnrieh station on the Khedive's railway. The ship is, in a great measure, protected from the sea by the reef, hut is ashore almft the funnel and leaking with 5 feet of water in her hold. The discharge of her cargo of paving stones to lighten her will he difficult.

div.head: An Assiout Sacred Cat.
div.p: Mark Twain has a gorgeous lie about the foundation of Cecil Rhodes's fortune, which tells how the future Empire builder caught n shark that had made a record passage from Europe carrying inside it a newspaper, whence Rhodes derived early and exclusive information as to the outbreak of the Franco-German war, and speculated accordingly. His surprise could hardly have been greater than that of the German lady who, as the "Tablet" recordn bought a mummified sacred cat at Assiout recently, and discovered inside it—a copy of the "Daily Mail" ! There is nothing new under the sun, then, after all. The journal that has revolutionised us all is simply cribbed from the days of Amasis. The discovery throws a decidedly new lighton the civilisation of Pharaonic Egypt, of wfiich intelligent anticipation appears to have been a notable characteristic. Of course, there is another conceivable explanation of the mystery ; but that must bo sconted in view of the. notorious trustworthiness of the vendors of antiquities in Egypt and throughout the world.

div.head: LORD CROMER'S WORK.
div.p: GREAT BRITAIN'S RECOGNITION.
ORDER OF GARTER PROBABLE.
(Caxette's Special Service.)
LONDON, Tuesday.

The "Tribune" in discussing the probable manner in which the nation will recognise the eminent services of Lord Cromer to his own country and to Egypt, says that it is understood-in well-informed circles that his lordship will be offered the Order of the Garter, which is the; highest honour which King Edward can donfer upon him. The conferment will have a great international significance in view of the fact that the Order is usually associated with Sovereignty. The full complement of the Order at present is twenty-four knights, but there is precedent for temporarily raising the number under special circumstances.

div.head: LORD CROMERS RESIGNATION.
div.p: "AL LEWA'S" CORRESPONDENT (?)
Lord Cromer's resignation.

In the "Egyptian Standard" of yesterday's date there appears a telegram purporting to come from the "London correspondent" of that paper, and pretending to give the true cause of Lord Cromer's resignation.

The construction of these sentences in this telegram is so very un-English, and the use of certain words so very unusual and peculiar, that were we not completely convinced of the absolute integrity of-the noble Tasha who directs the "Egyptian Standard" we might suspect the name of his London correspondent to be "Mrs. Harris."
For example, the telegram says -
1. "I have been told that this resignation has been produced by Sir Henry Cainpbell-Bannerman, the Premier, who was dissatisfied with Lord Cromer's policy since the Denslmwai incident."
Besides the strange use of the verb "produce" in this sentence, there is the characteristic Egyptiah confusion of "was" and "has been"
II. "To resolve the question Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman cut short etc."
III. I have received the above news from a sincere source and I hasten to give it to you

IV. Convocating the Council of Minsters Such an expression is utterly foreign, for the term Council of Ministers is most unusual as, also is "convocating." The expression which everybody would use in such a case would be "summoning a Cabinet Council." "Council of Ministers" is unknown and unused in England in application to the Cabinet Council and no-body would have thought of such a term as an equivalent in sending a telegram. The use of the above italicised words, and more especially the lack of true English idiom in the whole tele-gram appear to be absolute proof that it was not written by a bona-fide Englishman.
Who can the London Correspondent be Hère is the text of the telegram :—
London, April 14/(6.30 p.m )

I have learnt the cause of Lord Cromer's resignation. 1 have been told that this resignation hits been produced by Sir Henry Campbell- Bannerman, the Premier, who was dissatisfied with Lord Cromer's policy since the Deushawai incident. He insisted besides, since the resolutions of the General Assembly were known, upon the necessity of introducing reforms of the Blue Book.
GREEK FEELING
Last evening the Greek Community and the Greek Chamber of Commerce at Alexandria decided to seud to-day telegrams to Lord Cromer expressing their regretat his departure.
The Orthodox Patriarch of Alexandria, who is at Minieh, on hearing of his Lordship's resignation despatched a telegram expressing the regrets of thé Orthodox Church at his forthcoming departure.
THE MUNICIPAL COMMITTEE.
There will be a meeting of the special Muni

div.head: GHAZI MUKHTAR PASHA
div.p: MR. PITAUX'S INTERVIEW-
THE NATIONALIST MOVEMENT.
(Gazette's Speolal Service.)
LONDON, Tuesday.

In referring to Mr. Puaux's interview with Ghazi Mukhtar Pasha, appearing in the "Temps," the "Times" remarks that the blessing conferred upon Mustapha Pasha Kamel by the Turkish Pasha is more likely to weaken rather than strengthen whatever inclination sentimental politicians in European countries may have had to sympathise with Egyptian nationalism, as Mukhtar Pasha and Mustapha Pasha Kamel understand it. Iiord Cromer has taken measures to deni with the movement, as has been already explained to his countrymen. Naturally the champions of agitation resent exposure,as it can but lead to the estrangement of what sympathy European politicians may have had for them up to the present.
The following are the leading pointe of the interview referred to as telegraphed to "Al Lewa" :—

"I reside here in Cairo as a living protest against the British Occupation. If the Engjjph upon Turkey." The Marshal then reminds his interviewer of what Lord Palmerston said to hut only provisionally. Only sinoe the opening of the Hedjaz Railway as far as Moan h'ave English claims to the Sinai Peninsula suddenly appeared on the scene. The Marshal continues the interview by denying that he /had wished to create a war between Turkey and England. He likewise existence of Pan-Islainism, stating that it is an invention made' by England, who is bent upon obtaining the support of such Of the Powers as have interests in the East, against welcome guest at Constantinople.

THE NEW KHEDIVIAL HOTEL

It has been decided to continue thé New Khédivial Hotel at Alexandria without any very material alterations for another two years. The only changes, which are to be carried out, will be the introductions of steam heating and the installation of a large refrigerator. The clients of this hotel will be pleased to hear that Mr. Reinsperger will remain as manager.
The preparatons for the construction of the Ritz Hotel on the site of the Gallerie Lafeyette have already begun. It is said that it will be the most magnificent hotel in Egypt.

div.head: KING EDWARD AT MALTA.
div.p: ENTHUSIASTIC RECEPTION
SIR A. DINGLI'S MONUMENT.
(Gazette Special Service.)
LONDON, Tuesday.

King Edward and Queen Alexandra were met at Malta with a most loyal and magnificent reception, and the outburst of enthusiasm on all sides was immense. Yesterday morning theii Majesties witnessed the naval review and the King afterwards unveiled the monument to the late Sir Adrian Dingli, formerly Chief Justice ot Malta. The King's striking tribute to the great services which Sir Adrian Dingli had rendered to Malta produced a great sensation. Later in the day their Majesties held a brilliant levee at the Governor's house.

div.head: RAISING ASSOUAN DAM
EFFECT ON THE COTTON CROP.
div.p: The Egyptian government is determined to begin the raising of the Assouan Dam as soon as possible and last week a contract was signed by the Government with Messrs. John Aird and Co., the builders of tho dam, for increasing the height of tho dam by 24ft. The oontract, which Involves a sum of £1,500,000, will be entered upon almost immediately.

The result of the work will have an important bearing on the cotton crop. The area under cotton in 1906 is given as 4,506,290 acres. Taking the present cotton orop at 6jf millions kantaru, the average yield per acre works out to 4$ kantars. The area under cotton in Lower Egypt alone is 1,260,107 acres, this representing about 40 per cent, of the total cultivated area in that division of the country The whole of this area, being under perennial irrigation, is cotton-bearing. These figures, therefore, indicate that, on an average, cotton is grown on the same land two years out of five The area under cotton in Upper Egypt is given as 246,183 acres. This represents only a small proportion of the cultivated area, less than half of the latter being under perennial irrigation. Moreover, the climatic conditions south ôf Assiout are unfavourable for growing cotton. In order to ascertain to what extent the cotton-bearing area is susceptible of expansion, wo assumo that the whole of the hasin lands in the northern half of Uppor Egypt will ho brought under perennial irrigation, and that the uncultivated portions in both Upper and Lower Egypt will ultimately he reclaimed. Tho Cotton-bearing area will then extend over some 5,600,000 acres (being the total of 6,387,100 acres given above, less about 800,000 acres south of Assiout). On the basis of a 40 per cent, acreage per annum, and a yield of 4^ kantars per acre, this area might produce an arinual cotton crop of about 10,000,000 kantars. It is to he observed that a considerable portion of the land at present under cultivation is being improved, which will, without doubt, contribute to raise the average yield per acre. On the other side must he set the consideration that last year's crop was so favoured by à good Nile and satisfactory climatic conditions as to raise the average yield above the level of recent years. Of tho total of 10,000,000 kantars, no more than 7,000,000 kantars would consist of the Mitafifi, Abassi, and Yoannovitch varieties, for which the Delta is famous, the remaining 3,000,000 kantars representing the lowér-grade cotton produced in Uppor Egypt.
Lord Cromer in discussing these figures remarks :

"It will, of course, be understood that this crop of 10,000,000 kantars cannot be produced until hoth the supply of water has been largely increased, either by raising the Assouan dam or hy some other means, and until reclamation works on a large scale have been executed in Lower Egypt. Sir William Gars- tin—probably the highest authority on the subject—says,'—1 do not think that 10,000,000 kantars, as an eventual yield for the Egyptian cotton crop, is at all an impossible figure, but it will take many years to arrive at—probably ten or fifteen."

The Egyptian cotton orop might conceivably receive a still geater extension in course of time from two further sources, namely, the reclamation of the lakes in Lower Egypt and the development of the Oases.' The former, if ever carried out, would add some 800,000 acres to the cultivated area, and a further 1,500,000 kantars to the cotton crop. The latter is at present too problematical to permit of any estimate being made of the possible results.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA MUNICIPALITY
div.p: MEETING OF DELEGATION.

The Alexandria Municipal Delegation met yesterday afternoon under the presidency of Schieaa Pasha. At the opening 61 the meeting Lord Cromer's reply to the telegram of regret at his resignation sent by the Commission on Sunday was read. Concerning the decision of the Municipality to make vaccination obligatory for all persons disembarking at Alexandria, the Ministry of the Interior has informed them that great difficulty, would he found iu carrying out such a regulation and that it would be preferable to institute optional vaccination. The Delegation disapproved of the Ministry's suggestion and has abandoned the project. Note was taken of a project for the transformation of Mohamed Ali square ahd the creation of a new square on the grounds of the Jardin Français as far as the sea : it was decided to ask for an estimate of cost. The Delegation decided to return to the Ministry Public Works, wftli a favourable expression of opinion, the estimate for the transfer of the disinfection establishment and the hygiene laboratory. They decided to ask for a credit of L.K. 100 for the translation of the book of laws and regulations concerning the Municipality. The statement of receipts and expenditure for the first quarter of 1907 was read. Tho receipts of the ordinary budget totalled L.E. 64,631 and the expenditure L.E. 46,645. To the account of tho extraordinary budget the receipts were LE. 91,269, of which L.E. 88,'222 was tho lialanoe from last year, and the expenses L E. 58,630, undertaken by the Commission, leaving a credit of LE. 32,639. The sale of land on the quays during the quarter realised L E. 73,873. The delegation referred to the Finance Committee a proposal for the formation of a mutual help society among the employés of the Municipality.

div.head: THE FINANC1AL CRISIS.
div.p: The position o£ affairs on the bourse this morning was decidedly better. There are the usual crop of rumours floating about as to the line of policy which the hanks will collectively pursue, but all such rumours are entirely premature.

The fact is that the present pessimistic outlook is very much exaggerated, and although tho outlook is not by any means ( bright at tho present moment, the position is by no means as bad as it is made out to ho.

div.head: THE ANTI TUBERCULOSIS LEAGUE.
div.p: One of tho greatest private works which is now being carried on in Egypt, and one that is thoroughly deserving of a portion of the rich man's wealth and of the poor man's mite, is the fight against tuberculosis which is being made by an international body under the name of "La Ligue Egyptienne contre "la Tuberculose " By scanning the report of the Alexandria committee of this league for 1906 one is convinced of the great and useful work which is being performed hy it, hy the help which it extends to the poorer classes without distinction of nationality, and we do not hesitate to urge upon our readers the claim of this league to the best support which they can afford. In reviewing this report we observe that since its commencement in November 1903, 254 tubercular cases have been treated in Alexandria, 8,746 consultations have been given hy the dis-1 peii8ary in Tewfik Pasha Street, 892 invalids have been visited, of which 230 patients were recognised as tubercular, and 56 deaths occurred. In 1906, 3,278 consultations were given, 50 patients were recognised as tubercular, and.five deaths occurred. The dispensary j in Masguid Abdel Latif Street was opened in I June of last year, and the six months 1,649 consultations were given, 24 patients were recognised as tubercular, and 1 death wasj^- ported. The uomber of cases under treatment j in the two dispensaries on the 1st of February last was 153, and 96 cases were under observation. The aunual contributions to the league total L.E.57/175m. and the donations amount ' to L.E 87/662m. The league has started a subscription list for the construction of a home for tubercular cases and we are glad to note I that their appeal has been well responded to,
the donations at the time of publication of the . report totalling L.E. 496.

div.head: BRITISH COTTON CONFERENCE.
div.p: WEAVERS' DEMAND REFUSED
CHANCES OF A STRIKE
( Gazette Special Servloe. )
London, Wednesday.

The conference of cotton manufacturers sitting at Manchester has refused tho demand of the weavers for an additional 5 % advance on their wages. This decision affects 120,000 operatives and it is expected that a vote will be taken as to whether strike notices should be issued.

div.head: BADEN POWELL'S SUCCESSOR;
div.p: London, Wednesday.
Major-General Scobell succeeds Major-Genera* Baden Powell as inspector of cavalry on May 7th.

div.head: THE CAPITULATIONS.
div.p: THE SANCTION OF GERMANY.
The idea that the conflicting interests of two countries may be satisfactorily settled by means of mutual concessions in other domains seems to appeal to Germans.

A feeler is launched in the Berlin Press in connection with a discussion on the present phase of the Egyptian question. Germany's interests in Egypt, it is pointed out, are pujely commercial, but Germany's sanction is requisite before the Capitulations can be abolished dr altered, and this sanction being an object of value the suggestion is made that some compensation may be demanded in return for it. FRENCH COMMENT.
Commenting on Lord -Cromer's report, the "Journal des Débats" says :

"We do not want to arouse any anxiety about the tendency to disinternationalise the country which is now lining exhibited. So long as Great Britain, in her general policy and in minor questions, such as, for instance, in that of Abyssinia in the last few months, loyally observes towards us the spirit of the agreement we have only to follow and develop that same spirit ourselves in matters which may arise between the two countries. We cannot forgot that one of our agreements with Great Britain concluded on April 8, 1904. declared that the French Republic would place uo obstacle in the way of Great Britain's action in Egypt by demanding that a time limit should be set for her military occupation of that country or in any other way."

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: The King lias been graciously pleased to appoint James Henry Monahan, Esquire, to lie his Majesty's Consul for the Eastern Coast of the Red Sea, to reside at Jeddah.

Borton Bey, Assistant Postmaster General, will, it is believed, succeed Saba Pasha. As Peake Bey, the other Assistant Postmaster General, is retiring shortly from the Government service, the two posts of Assistant Postmaster General will lie both vacant.
Mohamed Bey Wahid, a notable of Helouun, has sent the following telegram to Lord Cromer :—

The country has been shaken hy the news, of your resignation. Regret is universal among Egyptians, especially at the reason that prompted resignation In the name of many among those.who have enjoyed the fruit? of your justice, I beg to give expression to our great regret.. We all heartily wish you speedy recovery and thank you sincerely for all you have done to reform our country, promote its welfare, and lay the foundations of permanent prosperity in it We shall always remember you with gratitude and consider you the greatest benefactor to Egypt and its people.

div.head:
COLONIAL CONFERENCE.
THK PREMIER'S GREETING.
HIS TRIBUTE TO CHAMBERLAIN.

div.p: Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman, welcoming the Premiers at the Colonial Conference, extended his special greetings to General Botha whom he described as the Benjamin of the Brotherhoo 1. He said that preference must hold a prominent position in the discussion of the Conference It was not empowered to form binding decisions. The Imperial Government cannot go behind the declared opinions of the country; nevertheless he believed that there were many mattera of moment in which there was room for arrangement and advance. .Sir H. Campbell-Bannerman payer! a glowing tribute to Mr. Chamberlain's work for the Empire.
(Reuter)

div.head:
FREEDOM OF CITY CONFERRED.
ROBERTS AND BOTHA MEET
LAURIER'S RESPONSE TO TOAST.

div.p: The Premiers this afternoon marched in procession through decorated streets from the Hotel Cecil to the Guildhall to receive the freedom of the City. The proceedings were marked by the stateliest ceremonial. Mr. Deakin returned thanks on behalf of his colleagues. The brilliant company present in eluded Cabinet Ministers, the Archbishop of Canterbury, high officials, and military naval officers.
Immediately after being introduced to the Ix>rd Mayor, General Botha met Lord Roberts on the dais when a most impressive handshak ing took place amid tumultuous cheering.

Sir W. Laurier, responding to the Lord, Mayor's toast, said that the Premiers had only to look round and see Dr. Jameson and General Botha to find an answer to the question whether the Conference would be a failure, The success of the Conference was assured and would demonstrate that the Empire was a living entity.
(Renter)

President Roosevelt, in a letter addressed to the Peace Congress, met here, urges the limitation of navies, the adoption of a general arbitration treaty, and the appointment of judges sitting permanently nt the Hague. (R.)

div.head:
EARTHQUAKE IN AMERICA.
TWO TOWNS DESTROYED

div.p: The towns of Chilpancingo and Chilapa were destroyed by earthquake on 14th instant. 38 persons were killed or injured.
(Reuter)
An earthquake in Mexico has destroyed Chilpalcingo and Chilapa. It is said that 500 people have perished.
(llax'as)
[We conclude that this earthquake is the one referred to yesterday in Havas' telegram from Paris as having been recorded by the German and Italian seismographs. Ed. E.G.]

div.head: EGYPT EXPLORATION FUND
div.p: PAST SEASON'S OPERATIONS.

Mr. Edouard Navillo contributes to the "Times" an instructive account of the operations carried out during the season just ended by the Egypt Exploration Find, which will interest our readers. Mr. Naville writes :—

The excavations of the Egypt Exploration Fund at Deir Bahari are drawing towards their close. During this campaign, with assistance of Mr. Currelly, Mr. Dennis, and Mr. Dalison, I have gone on digging out the oldest temple at Thebes, the sanctuary of Mentuhet- ep of the Xlth Dynasty, a King who left a name in Egypt, and to whom special honours were granted by his successors, as late as Rameses II. of the XIXth Dynasty.

This winter we made no such sensational discovery as last year. We cannot show a work of art as remarkable as the Hathor goddess, the sacred cow, who has been transported, with her shrine, to the museum in Cairo. But we discovered something which, though not being a museum object, is important, because it gives us some information as to the worship of same period last year, the difference thus being King Mentiihetep.

The temple of the Xlth Dynasty, discovered three years ago, has a peculiar form which at present is unique. It consists of a rock-platform to which access is given by a ramp. In the middle is a square mass of building which originally had a casing of white limestone ; it probably is the basement of a pyramid, tower-ing above a columned hall, for there are rows of columns on all sides. But the temple extends a great deal further back, towards th ofe lofty rocks forming majestic circle at the end of the valley of Deir el Bahari. The clearing of this part has been the work of the last weeks 1906, and of this campaign.

We first met with an open court lined on both sides with a single colonnade ; further we found remains of a hypostyle hall not yet completely excavated, but. where we can trace already 72 columns of the so-called protodoric style, and bearing the name of Neb-Hepet-Ra Mentuhetep.

In the open court, which we reached last year, we stopped at the entrance of a sloping passage extending down below the pavement, and t he door of which was obstructed by heaps of enormous stones and rubbish. We left the clearing of it for this year. We entered it a fortnight ago. It is a well cut rock tunnel, which goes dqwn quite straight for 150 mètres (about 500ft.). On more than half of itslengtl it is vaulted ; two kandstone blocks leaning against each other aj. the top, and cut in the form of an arch, rest! on the rock and on walls of dry stones erected qn both sides. Except at the entrance, where there was a pile of stones, the passage was free. Between the two walls there was a path sufficiently wide for a man to go down.

At the-end of the tunnel there is a room of granite made of big blocks extremely well joined, like the chambers in the pyramids. The door was blocked by a stone. One might have expected that this chainber was a tomb, but it seems clear that it had a different purpose. The greatest part of it is Occupied by a* great alabaster shrine, mode of huge blocks of that beautiful stone. Except a icornice and a moulding it has no sculpture or ornament of any kind. The ceiling is niado of an enormous monolithic red granite slab, over which comes again alabaster.

This shrine was empty except for a few well cut black granite stones, which were part of a casing inserted between the shrine and tho walls of the chamber. In my opinion this shrine was a sanctuary; it was the abode of the la, as the Egyptians culled the double or the image of the King, which was represented by a statue now destroyed. In front of the shrine there was a heap of broken wooden figures, fragments of fiirniture, and a quantity of cloth in which must have been wrapped offerings, or perhaps mummified animals, also a few small pieces of bones said to be human. But there was no trace of a wooden or stone coffin, no definite evidence of a burial. That is the reason why I consider this shrine as a sanctuary. This agrees with a decree found on a large stele at the entrance of the passage, in which a successor of Mentuhetep, of the following dynasty, orders that for what he calls "the cave of Mentuhetep" should be provided every day food and drink, and whenever a bull should be slaughtered in the great temple of Amon, roast meat should be brought to that cave These offerings are those of a god or of the King adored as such ; they are not funerary.

It must have been a place were priests htfd frequently to descend, since an arch was made over the passage evidently after the chamber and shrine had been finished. There would tiave been no reason for arching a passage leading to a closed funeral chamber.

The shrine, which is 3 metres 50 long, 2m. 25 wide, and 2m. 50 high, is striking by its fine architecture, and the beautiful material out of which it is made. It would be extremely difficult to remove it to a museum. It would be an expensive work, also somewhat dangerous. Besides, in a large hall it would by no means produce the same effect as it does in its subterranean granite chamber. It will remain for the present in its deep hiding place. The passage will lie closed by a door, so that people specially interested in Egyptian architecture may reach it ; for it is not advisable for tourists to go in, nor would they much enjoy it.

As it is, it has added a new feature to the temple of the Xlth Dynasty, which has been so rich ih unexpected architectural discoveries. The platform, the pyramid issuing out of a colonnade, the hypostyle hall, tho subterranean sanctuary, form a whole of a nature quite unique among Egyptian temples.

We first met with an open court lined on both sides with a single colonnade ; further we found remains of a hypostyle hall not yet completely excavated, but. where we can trace already 72 columns of the so-called protodoric style, and bearing the name of Neb-Hepet-Ra Mentuhetep.

We hope to finish the excavations at Deir el Bahari shortly. Then the two temples, built at more than a thousand years' interval, will be free, and the whole of the circus-like end of the valley will be visible.I feel bound to add that, except for one-third of the temple of the Queen whose popular name is Hatasoo, which was uncovered by Mariette, the clearing of the site of Deir el Bahari, now one of the chief attractions at Thebes, is entirely the work of the Egypt Exploration Fund. This great work, which lasted more than ten years, and which added monuments of priceless value to the Cairo Museum, to the British Museum, and to various other collections both in Europe and America, has been completely carried on by private subscriptions.

div.head: EGYPT'S TRADE.
div.p: FEBRUARY'S IMPORTS.

The total goods cleared through the Egyp-tian Customs during February were valued LE. 1,958,788 against LE. 1,623,055 for the same period last year, the difference thus being a gain of L.E 835,733 in favour of 1907. The above mentioned surplus of L E. 335,733 was mainly divided as follows : France L.E. 94,886, England L.E. 62,584, Germany L.E. 45.406, Austria L.E 38,889, and Turkey L.E. 20,100. Belgium dropped L.K 84,501 on the month,

Textiles as a class were L.E 89,907 higher, Coal and Cereals were respectively L.K 50,458 ing above a columned hall, for there are rows ' and L.E. 45,569 to the good, whilst the Parcels Post contributed no less than L.E 52,235 to the general increase. Only two out of the fifteen Customs categories showed a decline viz : Metals with a shrinkage of L.E 28,657 and Colonial Produce with a loss of L.E. 14,410.
Building Materials.
France with L E. 9,425 and Belgium with L E 7,355 were the largest shippers of lime, plaster and cement during February. England followed with L.K 4,964.
Coal.
The imports of coal were 128,920 tons against 83,144 tons last yea. The total shipments were declared at L,E. 111,451.
Flour.

The Hour returns were nearly L.K 20,000 better than those for the previous February. Over 60 % of the clearances of L.E. 118,756 were credited to France, thonghj it is satistac- tory to note that, after Russia with L.E. 18,048, England occupied the third position with L.E. 11,072. The total quantity of flour passed through the Customs was 14,783,393 kilos, being some 2 J million kilos more than in 1906.
Furniture.

The furniture returns still maintain an inward tendency the clearances for the month amounting to L.E 56,243. England was well in the front rank, her shipments of L.E. 12,700 being almost identical with Austria ami Prance. Italy contributed L.K 8,095.
Hoops.
Iron hoops to the extent of 204,544 kilus, valued at L.K 1,554, were delivered during February. These figures, as previously explained are included in tho iron and iron goods division.
Iron and Iron Goods.

The figures of L.E 123,559 for this classification do not show much improvement on those of last year. As a matter of fact, girders at 4,634 tons were 1,833 tonrf lower than in February 1906, though, on th# other hand, the goods classified by value were declared at LE. 92,102 against L E. 77,731. England was credited with L.E. 48,768, Belgium L.K 29,067, and Germany L.E 23,084.
Linen Goods.

Made up linen goods to the value of L.E. 43,996 were received during the month under revision, being an expansion of LE. 9,266 ovet last year. The principal shipping countries were France L.K 18,580, L E. 10,492, Germany L.K 6,247 anil Austria L.E 5,24tL
Locomotives and Rolling Stock,
The main causes of the shrinkage in the Metal category was the entire absence of rolling stock deliveries, and the fact that only LK 5,758 was credited to locomotives.
Manchester Goods.

Following the rush to clear Manchester goods during January, when an increase of L.E. 139,263 over 1906 was noted, the returns for February, although totalling LK 226,903, were only LE. 29,666 above the corresponding ^period of lost year. The details of the shipments, compared with 1906, areas follows :—
By weight : 1,455,617 kilos=L.K 180,942 against 1,454,972 kilos=L.K 162,875.
By measure : 2.357,137 inetres=LE 45,961 against 1,767,422 metres=L.K 34,363.
It will be observed that the average price per kilo of the goods classified by weight has risen some P.T. 1.3 (3jd) during the twelve months.

Although dearer goods are now arriving, it must not be forgotten tliat part of such increase of P.T. 1.3 was due to the change— mentioned in our February issue—in the Customs regulations now in force for valuing Manchester Goods.
Machinery-Agricultural.

'flie clearances at L E. 30,776 were L K 17,000 higher than last year. Germany did business with Egypt in this line to the extent of L K 5,077, Switzerland L E. 1,430, Amer ica L K 573, whilst England forwarded goods to the value of L.E. 29,316.
Machinery-General
An increase of L. K 22,000. The mam deliveries were England L.B 21,015, France LK 18,184 and Germany L.E. 7,529.
Rice
The amount of rice landed during Fhbrnary was 5,814,660 kilos valued at L.E. 48,114 against 3,346,412 kilos -L. E. 26,061 last year. Rangoon shipped rice to the value of L.E. 43,014.
Sugar.
2,231,278 kilos were cleared against 3,026,777 iiu 1906. Austria increased her shipments from L.E. 14,117 to L.E 25,353. On the other hand, China and the Far East had no boats discharging this year.
Sack*.
The whole of the sack deliveries of L. E. 12,832—except a small parcel of L.E. 22 from Turkey—came from India.
Timber.
The Timber figures at L.E. 62,986 showed a loss of L E. 28,352. Sweden sent L E 24,768, Russia L.E. 14,553, Austria LE. 14,182 and Turkey L.E. 5,590.
Tobacco.

Tobacco to the value of L.K 59,000 reached Egypt during the month.On the 28th February, the stock of tobacco in bond throughout the whole of the Egyptian Customs was 6 870,517 kilos or 155,707 bales. These figures are an increase of 825,736 kilos over the stocks held on the 31st December last.
England's Share.

England's returns for the month amounted to LE 632,517 being an increase of L. K 62,584 over Feb uary 1906. Her share of Egypt's total imports was thus 32.2 %, and of the country's increased, trade 18.6 %. Coal, Manchester Goods, and General Machinery were the principal factors on the credit side of the account, whilst Loconntivev and Rolling Stock caused a drop of over L.E. 80,000 in the British figares.
(British Chamber of Commerce Bulletin.)

div.head: CRIÇKET IN CAIRO.
div.p: RAILWAY INSTITUTE v. ROYAL ENGINEERS.

This match took place last Friday on the Institute ground. The homo captain, having won the toss put the Engineers in first. A bad start was mude, Windsor scattering Elsey's stumps first ball. Townsend only scored a single before being bowled. After Newton had left for a "duck," Davies and McCudden made a fair stand, but when the former was run out the side went to pieces before the bowling of the Rev. J. T Burns and P. G. Windsor. With a total of 46 to beat, Messrs. Burns and Windsor went to the wickets and soon knocked up 30, when the former was run out. Windsor then proceeded to give a brilliant display hitting in all directions. He treated Newton with scant courtesy, on one occasion sending him clean over the Institute roof, and it was not until he had knocked up 63 that Else)' caught him splendidly. All the home batsmen made a good show ami stumps were drawn with thescore at 169 lor 8 wickets, the Institute thus winning easily by 123 runs. The details of the scores are as follows :—

div.head: GYMNASTIC.
div.p: CAIRO POLICE SCHOOL.

A gymnastic display was given by the cadets of the Police School, Cairo, in the square of the school on Monday evening before a large number of ladies and gentlemen, chief among whom we noticed, the Counteas of Cromer, Sir William Garstjn, Sir Vincent Corbett, Mr. and Lady Valda Machell, Major- General and Mias Bullock, Judge and Mrs Chapcott, Fabmy Pasha, Fakhry Pasha, Coles Pasha, Mansfield Pasha, Saad Zaghloul Pasha, Mr. Dunlop, Major and Mrs. Elgood, Mr. Mcllwraith, Mr. Dunlop, Mr. Moherley. The physical drill display cannot be commented upon too highly ; the various movements wetè enacted with finish and agility, reflecting considerable credit on the men themselves and their instructors. The mounted company of the school went through various movements on horseback,each of which being accomplished in such a manner that a strong impression of thoroughness was accepted. The parade of the five companies of foot and one mpunted company presented a fine spectacle, while all acquitted themselves very creditably in each and every movement. Lady Valda Machell presented the prizes to the first ten cadets of the school who bad achieved success ip the recent examination. The guests partook of tea in the Commandant's garden, the catering arrangements being entrusted to the Grand Continental Hotel and under the direction of Mr. Braun.

div.head: BANQÛE D'ATHENES.
div.p: Le rapport sur l'exercice 1906 vient d'être publié. L'évènement le plus important de l'année a été la fusion de cette institution avec le Crédit Industriel de Grèce et, le placement dés actions de la quatrième série qui ont permis de porter le capital à 40 millions de drachmes et la réserve à 8,736,000 drachmes.

Le rapport s'étend sur les questions touchant la Société Privilégiée dans laquelle la Banque possède d'importants intérêts. La Société des Vins et Spiritueux a été fondée sous ses auspices, la participation de la Banque dans cette houvelle entreprise est Drs. 2.350 000. La créance de la Banque d'Athènes contre la Société Vinicole a été liquidée avec une perte de Dr. 725.000 qui a été entièrement amortie Avec les bénéfices de l'année dernière.

Une importante convention a été conclue avec le Gouvernement de Samos ayant pour objet la fondation dans cette lie d'une succursale de la Banque avec droit d'émettre des billets de Banque et destinée à devenir pour ainsi dire la Banque privilégiée de Sainos Cette donvention agréée par le Conseil d'Administration sera prochainement soumise à l'approbation du parlement Samiote et devra ensuite être ratifiée par S.M. le Sultan.

L'accroissement important dc3 opérations et l'augmentation du personnel, survenus surtout après l'augmentation du capital ont imposé au Conseil d'élargir l'installation de la Banque d'Athènes. -Les local occupé jusqu'ici par la Banque Industrielle étant devenu sa propriété par suite de la fusion, le Conseil a décidé de roconstririrff ce local sur de nouveaux plans permettant l'installation des services d'une manière plus aisée et de vendre à la Banque d'Orient son établissement actuel au prix de Dr. 570,000.
Voici en quels termes s'exprime le nouveau ilirecteur général M. Mazas parlant des agences égyptiennes :

" Je dois tout spécialement rehausser l'action " progressive do nos succursales d'Egypte " lesquelles profitant de la prospérité extra- " ordinaire de ce payB et bien dirigées nous ont " donné des résultats très satisfaisants en " égard aux moyens que nous avicjns mis à " leur disposition.
" De ma récente visite en Egypte j'emportai " 'la meilleure des impressions quant à la " richesse du pays, sa prospérité et la force de

l'élément hellénique qui occupe la première " place dans le commerce et les affaires en " général tout aussi bien en Egypte, qu'au " Soudan. J'ai donc la conviction que malgré " le progrès de nos succursales d'Egypte, noué " avons le devoir de songer à renforcer notre " Banque là-bas et à nous établir dans d'autres " points encore tant de l'Egypte que du Soudan,

" sûrs que si nous y réussissons par une combi- " naison convenable, non seulement nous servi- " rions nos intérêts d'une façon efficace mais " nous nous montrerions également utiles au " point de vue national en contribuant indi- " rectement au dévelopment des intérêts com- " merciaux helléniques et des. rapports com- " merciaux avec ces riches pays oil l'élément hellénique est florissant."

Les bénéfices nets de l'exercice écoulé s'élèvent à la somme de 3.823.305 dr. dépassant ceux de l'annéeprécédented'environdr.860.0!)0. Outre ces bénéfices ordinaires, la Banque a réalisé encore un bénéfice extraordinaire de dr. 9 millions qui est le produit de ln prime de la dernière émission. De cette somme 500,000 dr. ont été payés aux actionnaires de la Banque Industrielle à titre (le good will.

Profitant de ces résultats très satisfaisants, la nouvelle Direction Générale a cru devoir procéder à des amortissements sérieux qui se montent à dr. 1.824.012,90. Elle a proposé également de doter le fonds de réserve or-, dinaire de dr. 7.625.000.
L'Assemblée Générale vient de ratifier cette répartition et de déclarer un dividende de 10 drachmes par actiop.

Messrs. MCLAREN, Engineers, of Leeds, England, have sold a large number of Steam Ploughs and Kassabiehs in Egypt this year. Everyone who has land to cultivate, or to level, should see them at work. Amongst the purchasers are His Highness Prince Hussein Kamel Pacha, His Highness Prince Halim; The Wardan Estates Company have purchased seven Machines, Messrs. Zagdoun Freres two Machines, also Messrs. Jatrodakis, Bushrahanna, Alexandre Kouri Haddad, Mr. R. P. McGillivray, etc.

They can be seen at work any time on application to Mr. Peter McLaren, our permanent representative in Egypt, at Shepheard's Hotel, Cairo, or to our Agents, Messrs. Thos. Cook & Son (Egypt] Ltd., Boulac Engine Works, Cairo. Full information may also be obtained from Messrs. J. & H. McLAREN, Midland Engine Works, Leeds, England.

div.head: BULLETIN DR LA BOURSE
div.p: (Ajourd'hui a midi et demie).

Nous sommes heureux de pouvoir aujourd'hui enregistrer une reprise qui, quoique légère, ne manquera pas de donner une certaine vitalité à notre marché, ai éprouvé depuis quelque temps. Les transactions très nombreuses ont porté sur un grand nombre de valeur«. La Cassa di Sconto remonte à 210, la Delta à

2 15/10, l'iuvestmeut à 15/10, les Estates à 1 3/4, le Comptoir à 5 1/4, les Building à 4 13/10, le Crédit Franco à 5 1/2, l'Aboukir à 30, la United à 29/32, la Port Said Salt à 14/ les Markets à 5/ et l'Ordinary Khédivial Mail à 38 0. La Banque d'Orient et l'Union foncière sont demandées à 123 et 5 1/4 respectivement sans vendeurs

Les Ritz s'effondrent à 2 3/10 sur la mineur que le capital de la Société serait purli .i L.E. 1,000,000. Eu baisse également la Kamh li à 5 3/4, l'Obligation Crédit Foncier ancienne à 337 et la Fondateur Land Investment ù

On annonce la fondation de nouvelles ageii ces disposant de moyens financiers assez importants. La maison Emile Sisto «S: Co. vient notamment s'établir avec un capital de £21,500. Le moment est, en effet, très opportun pour un emploi rémunérateur «le capitaux sur notre place.

lie taux de Te'C'mpte libre i Londres a> été encore ré-Ioit hier de 1/8 à 3 1/2 po r cent. Au Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a baissé de 1/8 & 86 3/8. L'Uuifiée est restée invariée & 101 3/4. La National Bank est rer. soignée à 24 1/2, ex coopon, soit en reml d'en viron 3/8 L'Agricole a jerdo 1/8 à H 3/4, de môme que la Dsïra à 15 5/8 et la Delta Light k 10 1/2.
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien a baifsé de 6 franos à 729 et la Ba- que d'Athènes del franc à 126.

lui, la séanoe d'aujourd'hui a été la continuation de celle d'hier, avec accentuation de la baisse sar les valeurs qui étaient offertes. La nouvelle de la sospension des paiements d'une maison de oourtage d'Alexandrie, ainsi que la mauvaise tenue du coton, ont oontriboé à augmenter le malaise et à aviver les inqniétndes. La senle noter assurante est qu'à la suite deB démarches faites hier une réunion des chefs des établissements défia1 que se tiendra cet apte* mid', à la National Bank, à l'tflot d'aviser sans retard aux mesures qui pourraient assister efficace «ent le marché.

Dans le compartiment des Banques, la National a o'ôturé à 211/2 ex coopon, soit en baisse d'environ 3/8. L'Agricole s'est tas ée à 8 11/16-3/4. La Cassa di Soon to a faibli À 2^8. Le Comptoir Finanoiera tléohi à 5 1/9.

Le Crédit Foncier a été i égligé à 730 ; sa part de fondateur est dasoendae à c00 ; l'obli gation à lots auoienne a progressé à 339 340. La Nile Land a perdu 2 livres à 26 1/2. L'Im mobilière a molli à 369. L'Agrioole dn Nil a été traitée k 246. L'Allotmont est tombé â 2 1/2.

Les Entreprises Immobi ières et Travanx se sont maintenues à 9 nominal ; leur part a été ramenée à 85. L'Epargne I mmobilière est restée à 2 3/8 ; sa part a clôturé à 91. La part de fondateur Express Nile a réaotionné à 117
Dans le groupe des valeurs hô'e'ières, les Nuugovioh ont été dé'ais-és à 25 3/4. Le» Egyptian out baissé k 8 5/8 11/16. Les National se sont raffermis à 2 7/8-15/16 et leur part k 45 47

Parmi les petites valeurs, la Delta Land a recalé à 2 15/16, les Estates à 1 11/16 et lear part à 16 1/2. Los Nev Egyptian sont revenus k 22 sh. les M .rkets à 23 sb. 1 1/2, les Sait and Soda à 19 sb. 1 1/2 et les R'tz Hotels à 2 1/2!
K en de particulier à relever sar les antres valeur?, q li u'onf, d'ailleurs, pas été négo ciées.

L'assemblée générale ordinaire de la Société Anonyme Egyptienne de Publicité a en lieu bie , à 4 heures de l'après-midi, au siège de la Sooiété 1 549 acti >ns étaient représentées. Lecture a é*é donnée du rapport du Conseil d'admiuistratiou et de celoi da oensenr. Les bénéfices nets de l'exercice se sontétavés k L E 2,132,90, après amortissement de tonies Irais d'émission et de première installation Le conseil a proposé de mettre L E. 100 h I» réserve et, après paiement des intérô's, du d vidende, etc., de reporter k nouveau le soldi de L.E. 81,94 *

L'assemblée a approuvé les comptes à l'unn «limité et a décidé de distribuer uo dividend» do P.E. 45 aux actions ordinaires, représenta»' le 15 % sur le raontaut versé, et de P.E. 27 aux parts de fondatear.

div.head: The Ritz Hotels (Egypt) Limited.
div.p: NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN that n General Meeting of the holders of the Pro .ferred ordinary shares in the capital of the Company will be held ftt the offices of Maitre Carton «le Wiart at Standard Building, Sharia Kasr el-Nil on Thursday, the 25th clay of April 1907 at 3.45 o'clock in the afternoon, for the purpose of considering, and if thought fit passing the subjoined resolution.

"That the provisional agreement dated the 15th day of April 1907 made between the Company of the one part ami Franz Sofio of tlie other part on liehalf of the holders of the preferred ordinary shares in the capital of the Company consenting to the conversion or exchange of the 5,000 de fei red ordinary shares for 100,000 preferred ordinary shares of the Company of £1 each lieing at the rate of 20 fully paid preferred ordinary shares for every «leferred ordinary share and to the increase of the capital of the Company by tlïe creation of 850,000 new preferred ordinary shares of £1 each lie an«l is hereby approved."
30058-1 Dated the 17th day of April 1907.

div.head: The Ritz Hotels (Egypt) Limited.
div.p: NOTICE HEREBY GIVEN, that an Extraordinary General Meeting of The Ritz Hotels (Egypt) Limited will he held at the offices of Maître Carton de Wiart, at Standard Buildings, Chareh Kasr el Nil, Cairo, on the 25th day of April, 1907 at 4 o'clock in the afternoon, when the subjoined Resolutions will lie proposed.

1) That it is desirable that t-lip business ami uffairs of the Company should henceforth he managed and directed from Egypt, ami that Board Meetings be held either in Cairo or Alexandria, and that accordingly clauses Nos. 1, 81, 82, .84, 88, 92, 99.J01, 103, 108 109 and 129 of the Company's Articles of Association be altered in such uiaimer ami form as may he determined \>y the Meeting.

2) That the plots of laud mentioned in the Agreement referred to in this Resolution belonging to The Nile Land and Agricultural Company being part of the Garden City, Cairo, and containing altogether about 93,000 square metres of laud, he acquired by the Company in consideration of the allotment to the Nile Lands and Agricultural Company of 450,INK) fully paid Preferred Ordinary Shares, subject to and upon the terms and conditions set forth in an agreement dated the tenth day of April 10«*7 made between the Nile Lands and Agri cultural Company of the first part, Charles Bams of the second part, and the Company ot •the third part (a copy of which agreement has beén read to the Meeting), or any modification thereof which may he approved by the Di rectors.

3) That the conditional agreement dated the twelfth day of April, 1907, and made between the Company of the one part and The Nile Lands and Agricultural Company and Charles Bacos of the other part he and the same is hereby approved, and that subject to the authority of Parliament being obtained for the purpose the 5,ono Deferred Ordinary Shares of the Company of One Shilling each which have been issued and are fully paid up he converted into and exchanged for 100,000 fully paid up Preferred Ordinary Shares of the Company of One Pound each, such conversion or exchange being at the rate of twenty fully paid Preferred Ordinary Shares for every Deferred Ordinary Share, and that the Directors be and are hereby authorised to have prepared an Act of Parliament for the purpose of enabling such conversion and exchange to be effected and to have such Act when so prepared promoted in Parliament

4) That having regard to the two Provisional Agreements respectively submitted to aiul approved by this meeting by the two last preceding resolutions and to the agreement dated the twelfth «lay of April 1907 made between the Company of the one part and Franz Sofio on behalf of all the holders of Preferred Ordinary Shares in the capital of the company of the other part, now submitted to this Meeting, which last mentioned agreement has lifccn ratified by an Extraordinary Resolution passed at a separate Meeting by the holders of Preferred Ordinary'Shares and Vrith a view to providing further capital for the purposes of the Company, the capital of the company he increased by the creation of

850.0 Preferred Ordinary Shares of One Pound each ranking in all respects pari passu with the 150,000 Preferred Ordinary Shares already issued and that as regards 300,000 Preferred Ordinary Shares part of such new
850.0 Preferred Ordinary Shares, the Directors he and are hereby authorised to issue them at such terms ami conditions as tjiey may think proper

; 5) That an agreement made the tenth clay of April 1907 between this company of the ohe part and Messrs. Henry Vincent Higgins and Theodore Matesdorf of the other part for the payment of compensation to them in rôspectof their loss of office as Directors be confirmed.

'Should the above resolution number one lié passed by the requisite majority it will he submitted for confirmation As a special résolu tiOn to a further* Extraordinary General Meet ing which will he subsequently convened.
Dated the 17th «lay of April, 1907
By Order of the Board ERRtfL KERR.
Secretary in Egypt.

Messieurs les Actionnaires do la National Bank of Egypt, sont convoqués en Assemblée Générale Extraordinaire pour le samedi vingt Avril 1907 à 3.30 de l'après-midi, au Siège j Social, au Caire, afin de délibérer sur la proposition suivante :
Augmentation du Capital Social et modification de l'article 10 des Statuts.

Tout actionnaire possédant au moins vingt, actions a droit de prendre part à l'Assemblée Généra le àeondition de déposer ses actions dans l'un dè.y5 lienx ci-après désignés oîi il lui sera délivreLtme Mi rte d'admission :

div.p: L'Administration des. Posées met en adjudication lo service des transports postaux dans lu ville d'Alexandrie au moyen de fourgons automobiles.

Las offres seront reçues jusqu'au 15 Mai 1907 inclusivement, elles devront être dressées sur papier timbré et transmises sous double- thiveloppe, celle extérieure adressée à M. le Directeur Général des Postes et celle intérieure portant la.Mention "'Offre pour transports par automobile".

div.head: A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.
div.p: This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality—vigour--
VITAL STRENGTH & ENERGY
to throw off these morbid feelings, and experience proves that as night succeeds the day this may be more certainly secured by a course of the celebrated life-reviving tonic
THERAPION No.3
than by any other known combination. So surely as it is taken in accordance with the printed directions accompanying it, will the shattered health be restored,
THE EXPIRING LAMP OF LIFE LIGHTED UP AFRESH,

and a new existence imparted in place of what had so lately seemed worn-out, "used up," and valueless. This wonderful medicament is purely vegetable and innocuous, is agreeable to the taste —suitable for all constitutions and conditions, in either sex; and it is difficult to imagine a case of disease or derangement, whose main features are those of debility, that will not be speedily and permanently benefited by this never-failing recuperative essence, which is destined to cast into oblivion everything that had preceded it for this wide-spread and numerous class of human ailments.
THERAPION

is sold by the principal Chemists throughout the world. Price in England, 2 9 and 4/6. Purchasers should see that the word 'THERAPION' appears on British Government Stamp (in white letters on a red ground) affixed to every package by order of His Majesty's Hon. Commissioners, and without which it is a forgery.
